case_name: West Ramnad Electric Distribution Co. Ltd. v. State of Madras

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 512 and 513 of 1960 appealed from Madras High Court judgment dated March 27, 1956 in Writ Petition Nos. 326 of 1955 and 107 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 5 1 2 and 513 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 27, 1956, of the Madras High Court, in Writ Petition Nos. 326 of 1955 and 107 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant West Ramnad Electric Distribution Co. Ltd., Rajapalayam incorporated in 1935 to carry on electric supply business under Indian Electricity Act of 1910 license.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the West Ramnad Electric Distribution Co. Ltd., Rajapalayam, was incorporated in 1935 to carry on, within the State of Madras and elsewhere, the business of an electric light and power companypany, to companystruct, lay down and establish and carry on all necessary installations, to generate, accumulate, distribute and supply electricity under a licence granted under the Indian Electricity Act of 1910.

facts.text: Madras Legislature passed Act XLIII of 1949 on January 24, 1950 for acquisition of electricity undertakings.

anchor.surface_text: On the 24th January, 1950, the Madras Legislature passed an Act  XLIII  of 1949  for the acquisition of undertaking supplying electricity in the Province of Madras.

facts.text: State of Madras passed Order C.O. Ms. No.2059 on May 17, 1951 declaring appellant undertaking vests from September 21, 1951 under s.4 of 1949 Act.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the provisions of s.4 1  of the said Act, the respondent, State of Madras, passed on Order C.O. Ms. No.2059 on the 17th May, 1951, declaring that the appellant undertaking shall vest in the respondent from the 21st September, 1951.

facts.text: Chief Electrical Inspector took possession of appellant undertaking, assets, records on appointed day September 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondent appointed the Chief Electrical Inspector as the Acquisition Officer, and on the appointed day, the said Officer took over possession of the appellant and all its assets, records and account- books.

facts.text: Respondent paid Rs. 6 lakhs to appellant on October 24, 1952 as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then paid over to the appellant Rs. 6 lakhs on the 24th October, 1952 and Rs. 2,34,387-1-0 on the 5th July, 1953, as companypensation.

facts.text: Respondent paid Rs. 2,34,387-1-0 to appellant on July 5, 1953 as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then paid over to the appellant Rs. 6 lakhs on the 24th October, 1952 and Rs. 2,34,387-1-0 on the 5th July, 1953, as companypensation.

facts.text: Appellant claims Rs. 98,876-15-0 balance compensation due under 1949 Act; respondent claims only Rs. 6000 due.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant-, Rs. 98,876-15-0 still remained to be paid to it by way of companypensation under the Act, whereas the respondent suggested that only Rs. 6000/was the balance due to the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court held 1949 Act ultra vires on February 10, 1954 in Rajamundry Electric Supply Corporation Ltd. v. State of Andhra.

anchor.surface_text: By its decision in the Rajamundry Electric Supply Corporation Ltd. v. The State of Andhra  2 , this Court held that the impugned Act of 1949 was ultra vires. This decision was based on the ground that the Act was beyond the legislative companypetence of the Madras Legislature...

facts.text: Madras Electricity Supply Undertakings Acquisition Act, 1954 (XXIX of 1954) received President's assent on October 9, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: After the decision of this Court was pronounced in the case of Rajamundry Electric Supply Corpn. Ltd.  1 , the Madras Legislature passed the Act and it received the assent of the President on the 9th October, 1954, and was published in the Government Gazette on the 13th October, 1954.

facts.text: 1954 Act published in Government Gazette on October 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: After the decision of this Court was pronounced in the case of Rajamundry Electric Supply Corpn. Ltd.  1 , the Madras Legislature passed the Act and it received the assent of the President on the 9th October, 1954, and was published in the Government Gazette on the 13th October, 1954.

facts.text: Respondent issued Government Order No. 4388 on December 14, 1954 appointing Chief Electrical Inspector as Acquisition Officer for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act was passed, the respondent issued a new Government Order No. 4388 on the 14th December, 1954, appointed the Chief Electrical Inspector to be the Acquisition Officer of the appellant companycern for purposes of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 326 of 1955 on April 26, 1955 challenging 1954 Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is under-these circumstances that the appellant filed its writ petition No. 326 of 1955 on the 26th April, 1955. In its writ petition, the appellant alleged that to the extent to which the Act purports to validate acts done under the earlier Act of 1949, it is ultra vires...

facts.text: Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 107 of 1956 on January 31, 1956 seeking restoration or market value.

anchor.surface_text: Later, the appellant filed an- other writ petition No. 107 of 1956 on the 31st January, 1956, and it added a prayer that a writ of Mandamus or any other writ, or order, or direction should be issued directing the respondent to restore possession of the appellant undertaking...

facts.text: Madras High Court dismissed writ petitions holding 1954 Act and s.24 valid.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Rajagopalan who beard the two writ petitions, rejected the companytentions raised by the appellant and dismissed the said petitions. He held that having regard to the fact that the appellant had accepted companypensation under the earlier Act...

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 132 for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: After this decision was pronounced, the appellant moved the learned Judge for a certificate under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution and it is with the certificate thus granted to it under the said Article that the present appeals have been brought to this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on May 2, 1962 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. May 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-The principal question which arises in these two appeals is related to the validity of s.24 of the Madras Electricity Supply Undertakings  Acquisition  Act, 1954  XXIX of 1954   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.24 of 1954 Act retrospectively validates actions under 1949 Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have numberdoubt that s. 24 was intended to validate actions taken under the earlier Act and on its fair and reasonable companystruction, it must be held that the intention has been carried out by the legislature by enacting the said section.

facts.text: Supreme Court held 1954 Act's s.5 compensation principles consistent with Art. 31(2).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the challenge to the validity of the Act on the ground that its important provisions companytained in section 5 offend against Art. 31  2  must be rejected.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Appellant appointed liquidator as Accredited Representative for compensation claims.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then appointed the liquidator as its Accredited Representative for the purposes of the Act in order to claim companypensation under the Act.

facts.text: Constitution of India came into force on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, the Constitution came into force on the 26th January, 1950, and the position of the legislative companypetence of the Madras Legislature in respect of the companypulsory acquisition of companymercial or industrial undertakings for public purposes has been materially altered.

holdings.text: Section 24 of the Madras Electricity Supply Undertakings Acquisition Act, 1954 is valid and retrospectively validates actions taken under the invalid 1949 Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt that s. 24 was intended to validate actions taken under the earlier Act and on its fair and reasonable construction, it must be held that the intention has been carried out by the legislature by enacting the said section. Therefore, the argument that s. 24, even if valid, cannot effectively validate the impugned notification, cannot succeed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fair and reasonable construction of s.24; Act's scheme retrospective; validates notifications properly issued under 1949 Act if not repugnant to 1954 Act.

holdings.text: Section 24 effectively sustains the 1951 order declaring vesting of the undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt that s. 24 was intended to validate actions taken under the earlier Act and on its fair and reasonable construction, it must be held that the intention has been carried out by the legislature by enacting the said section. Therefore, the argument that s. 24, even if valid, cannot effectively validate the impugned notification, cannot succeed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.24 declares valid actions under 1949 Act as valid under 1954 Act; impugned order properly issued assuming 1949 Act valid.

holdings.text: The impugned notification does not contravene Article 31(1) due to retrospective operation supplying authority of law.

anchor.surface_text: If the Act is retrospective in operation and s. 24 has been enacted for the purpose of retrospectively validating actions taken under the provisions of the earlier Act, it must follow by the very retrospective operation of the relevant provisions that at the time when the impugned notification was issued, these provisions were in existence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrospective law provides authority of law at deprivation time; contrasts with Art.20(1) specifying 'law in force at the time'.

holdings.text: Legislature competent to enact retrospective laws validating actions under void laws, including those void for contravening fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion, therefore, is that the appellants contention that it was beyond the competence of the Madras Legislature to make the Act retrospective so as to validate the impugned notification, cannot be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No distinction between voidness for lack of competence or FR violation; cites precedents like Madan Gopal, Sundararamier affirming retrospective legislative power.

holdings.text: Section 5 of the 1954 Act does not offend Article 31(2) as it provides principles for just equivalent compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the challenge to the validity of the Act on the ground that its important provisions contained in section 5 offend against Art. 31(2) must be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No material shows inadequacy; Bases A,B,C prima facie ensure just equivalent; licensee chooses basis; lacks evidence of true value.

holdings.text: Material provisions of the 1954 Act are retrospective, applying to undertakings taken over before commencement.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that the Act, in terms, is intended to apply to undertakings of which possession had already been taken, and that obviously means that its material and operative provisions are retrospective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definitions (s.2), ss.3,4,7,10,11,14 distinguish pre and post-commencement takeovers; scheme covers both.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges to Act rejected on merits.

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt that s. 24 was intended to validate actions taken under the earlier Act and on its fair and reasonable construction, it must be held that the intention has been carried out by the legislature by enacting the said section. Therefore, the argument that s. 24, even if valid, cannot effectively validate the impugned notification, cannot succeed.
The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: If the Act is retrospective in operation and s. 24 has been enacted for the purpose of retrospectively validating actions taken under the provisions of the earlier Act, it must follow by the very retrospective operation of the relevant provisions that at the time when the impugned notification was issued, these provisions were in existence.
The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.
